inspired by Raymond Carver’s masterpiece, is a provocative portrait of two marriages in which the Holocaust is played out as a devastating parlor game. In the outlandishly dark “Camp Sundown” vigilante justice is undertaken by a group of geriatric campers in a bucolic summer enclave. “Free Fruit for Young Widows” is a small, sharp study in evil, lovingly told by a father to a son. “Sister Hills” chronicles the history of Israel’s settlements from the eve of the Yom Kippur War through the present, a political fable constructed around the tale of two mothers who strike a terrible bargain to save a child. Marking a return to two of Englander’s classic themes, “Peep Show” and “How We Avenged the Blums” wrestle with sexual longing and ingenuity in the face of adversity and peril. And “Everything I Know About My Family on My Mother’s Side” is suffused with an intimacy and tenderness that break new ground for a writer who seems constantly to be expanding the parameters of what he can achieve in the short form. \xa0 Beautiful and courageous, funny and achingly sad, Englander’s work is a revelation. In the outlandishly dark &amp;ldquo;Camp Sundown&amp;rdquo; vigilante justice is undertaken by a group of geriatric campers in a bucolic summer enclave. &amp;ldquo;Free Fruit for Young Widows&amp;rdquo; is a small, sharp study in evil, lovingly told by a father to a son. &amp;ldquo;Sister Hills&amp;rdquo; chronicles the history of Israel&amp;rsquo;s settlements from the eve of the Yom Kippur War through the present, a political fable constructed around the tale of two mothers who strike a terrible bargain to save a child. Marking a return to two of Englander&amp;rsquo;s classic themes, &amp;ldquo;Peep Show&amp;rdquo; and &amp;ldquo;How We Avenged the Blums&amp;rdquo; wrestle with sexual longing and ingenuity in the face of adversity and peril. And &amp;ldquo;Everything I Know About My Family on My Mother&amp;rsquo;s Side&amp;rdquo; is suffused with an intimacy and tenderness that break new ground for a writer who seems constantly to be expanding the parameters of what he can achieve in the short form.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n &amp;#160;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n Beautiful and courageous, funny and achingly sad, Englander&amp;rsquo;s work is a revelation."/>\n\t\n    \n\t<title>Listen to What We Talk About When We Talk About Anne Frank: Stories by Nathan Englander at Audiobooks.com  </title>\n\n            <!-- Facebook Pixel Code -->\n      </div>\r\n                                                                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-written-by">Written By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/author/16342/nathan-englander">Nathan Englander</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-narrated-by">Narrated By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/narrator/24441/various-readers">Various Readers </a></span></span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-by">Publisher: <span class="nobold">Random House (Audio)</span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-date">Date: <span class="nobold">February 2012</span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                                                            <h4 class="book-duration">Duration: <span class="nobold">7 hours 0 minutes</span></h4>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                        <h4 class="book-summary nopadding">Summary:</h4>\r\n                        <div class="book-description">\r\n                            <p class="hide">These eight new stories from the celebrated novelist and short-story writer Nathan Englander display a gifted young author grappling with the great questions of modern life, with a command of language and the imagination that place Englander at the very forefront of contemporary American fiction.<br />\r\n &#160;<br />\r\n The title story, inspired by Raymond Carver&rsquo;s masterpiece, is a provocative portrait of two marriages in which the Holocaust is played out as a devastating parlor game. In the outlandishly dark &ldquo;Camp Sundown&rdquo; vigilante justice is undertaken by a group of geriatric campers in a bucolic summer enclave. &ldquo;Free Fruit for Young Widows&rdquo; is a small, sharp study in evil, lovingly told by a father to a son. &ldquo;Sister Hills&rdquo; chronicles the history of Israel&rsquo;s settlements from the eve of the Yom Kippur War through the present, a political fable constructed around the tale of two mothers who strike a terrible bargain to save a child. Marking a return to two of Englander&rsquo;s classic themes, &ldquo;Peep Show&rdquo; and &ldquo;How We Avenged the Blums&rdquo; wrestle with sexual longing and ingenuity in the face of adversity and peril. And &ldquo;Everything I Know About My Family on My Mother&rsquo;s Side&rdquo; is suffused with an intimacy and tenderness that break new ground for a writer who seems constantly to be expanding the parameters of what he can achieve in the short form.<br />\r\n &#160;<br />\r\n Beautiful and courageous, funny and achingly sad, Englander&rsquo;s work is a revelation.</p>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                                                <h4>Genres: <div itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" class="no-margin-bottom nobold" id="genre_0"><a class="nobold" var selector = $(\'form[method="post"]\');\n        if(selector.on){\n            selector.on(\'submit\', function(){\n                $(\'<input />\').attr(\'type\', \'hidden\')\n                    .attr(\'name\', "formy_form_token")\n                    .attr(\'value\', "ba87d27b9c0a76ea59dae6eaefdbc298")\n                    .appendTo(this);\n                return true;\n            })\n        }\n        else{\n            selector.live(\'submit\', function(){\n                $(\'<input />\').attr(\'type\', \'hidden\')\n                    .attr(\'name\', "formy_form_token")\n                    .attr(\'value\', "ba87d27b9c0a76ea59dae6eaefdbc298")\n                    .appendTo(this);\n                return true;\n            })\n        }\n    });\n</script><div id="footer" href="/browse/author/193060/ann-abramson">Ann Abramson</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-narrated-by">Narrated By: <span class="nobold"><span                         <h4 class="book-duration">Duration: <span class="nobold">0 hours 43 minutes</span></h4>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                        <h4 class="book-summary nopadding">Summary:</h4>\r\n                        <div class="book-description">\r\n                            <p class="hide">In her amazing diary, Anne Frank revealed the challenges and dreams common for any young girl. But Hitler brought her childhood to an end and forced her and her family into hiding.&#160;Who Was Anne Frank?&#160;looks closely at Anne&rsquo;s life before the secret annex, what life was like in hiding, and the legacy of her diary.</p>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                                                <h4>Genres: <div itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" class="no-margin-bottom nobold" id="genre_0"><a class="nobold" itemprop="url" href="https://www.audiobooks.com/browse/kids" genre-id="255"><span 'https://covers.audiobooks.com/images/covers/full/9781630157661.jpg', None, "In this controversial and provocative book, Mary Anne Franks examines the thin line between constitutional fidelity and constitutional fundamentalism. Constitutional fundamentalists read the Constitution selectively and self-servingly. Fundamentalist interpretations of the Constitution elevate certain constitutional rights above all others, benefit the most powerful members of society, and undermine the integrity of the document as a whole. The conservative fetish for the Second Amendment (enforced by groups such as the NRA) provides an obvious example of constitutional fundamentalism; the liberal fetish for the First Amendment (enforced by groups such as the ACLU) is less obvious but no less influential. Economic and civil libertarianism have increasingly merged to produce a deregulatory, 'free-market' approach to constitutional rights that achieves fullest expression in the idealization of the Internet. The worship of guns, speech, and the Internet in the name of the Constitution has blurred the boundaries between conduct and speech and between veneration and violence. But the Constitution itself contains the antidote to fundamentalism. The Cult of the Constitution lays bare the dark, antidemocratic consequences of constitutional fundamentalism and urges listeners to take the Constitution seriously, not selectively. Fundamentalist interpretations of the Constitution elevate certain constitutional rights above all others, benefit the most powerful members of society, and undermine the integrity of the document as a whole. The conservative fetish for the Second Amendment (enforced by groups such as the NRA) provides an obvious example of constitutional fundamentalism; the liberal fetish for the First Amendment (enforced by groups such as the ACLU) is less obvious but no less influential. Economic and civil libertarianism have increasingly merged to produce a deregulatory, \'free-market\' approach to constitutional rights that achieves fullest expression in the idealization of the Internet. The worship of guns, speech, and the Internet in the name of the Constitution has blurred the boundaries between conduct and speech and between veneration and violence.&lt;br /&gt;\n&lt;br /&gt;\nBut the Constitution itself contains the antidote to fundamentalism. The Cult of the Constitution lays bare the dark, antidemocratic consequences of constitutional fundamentalism and urges listeners to take the Constitution seriously, not selectively."/>\n\t\n            <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-written-by">Written By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/author/213144/mary-anne-franks">Mary Anne Franks</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-narrated-by">Narrated By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/narrator/167970/teri-schnaubelt">Teri Schnaubelt</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-by">Publisher: <span class="nobold">Tantor Media</span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-date">Date: <span class="nobold">July 2019</span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                                                            <h4 class="book-duration">Duration: <span class="nobold">8 hours 58 minutes</span></h4>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                        <h4 class="book-summary nopadding">Summary:</h4>\r\n                        <div class="book-description">\r\n                            <p class="hide">In this controversial and provocative book, Mary Anne Franks examines the thin line between constitutional fidelity and constitutional fundamentalism.<br />\n<br />\nConstitutional fundamentalists read the Constitution selectively and self-servingly. Fundamentalist interpretations of the Constitution elevate certain constitutional rights above all others, benefit the most powerful members of society, and undermine the integrity of the document as a whole. The conservative fetish for the Second Amendment (enforced by groups such as the NRA) provides an obvious example of constitutional fundamentalism; the liberal fetish for the First Amendment (enforced by groups such as the ACLU) is less obvious but no less influential. Economic and civil libertarianism have increasingly merged to produce a deregulatory, \'free-market\' approach to constitutional rights that achieves fullest expression in the idealization of the Internet. The worship of guns, speech, and the Internet in the name of the Constitution has blurred the boundaries between conduct and speech and between veneration and violence.<br />\n<br />\nBut the Constitution itself contains the antidote to fundamentalism. The Cult of the Constitution lays bare the dark, antidemocratic consequences of constitutional fundamentalism and urges listeners to take the Constitution seriously, not selectively.</p>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                                                <h4>Genres: <div itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" class="no-margin-bottom nobold" id="genre_0"><a class="nobold" itemprop="url" href="https://www.audiobooks.com/browse/non-fiction" genre-id="16"><span itemprop="title">Non-Fiction</split></a> &gt; <div itemscope itemprop="child" itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" style="display:inline;"><a class="nobold" itemprop="url" href="https://www.audiobooks.com/browse/non-fiction/law" genre-id="196"><span itemprop="title">Law</split></a></div></div></h4>\r\n                        <!-- <h4>Tags:</h4> -->\r\n                    </div>\r\n                    <div class="line"></div>\r\n\r\n                         <h4 class="book-duration">Duration: <span class="nobold">0 hours 43 minutes</span></h4>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                        <h4 class="book-summary nopadding">Summary:</h4>\r\n                        <div class="book-description">\r\n                            <p class="hide">In her amazing diary, Anne Frank revealed the challenges and dreams common for any young girl. But Hitler brought her childhood to an end and forced her and her family into hiding.&#160;Who Was Anne Frank?&#160;looks closely at Anne&rsquo;s life before the secret annex, what life was like in hiding, and the legacy of her diary.</p>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                                                <h4>Genres: <div itemscope inspired by Raymond Carver’s masterpiece, is a provocative portrait of two marriages in which the Holocaust is played out as a devastating parlor game. In the outlandishly dark “Camp Sundown” vigilante justice is undertaken by a group of geriatric campers in a bucolic summer enclave. “Free Fruit for Young Widows” is a small, sharp study in evil, lovingly told by a father to a son. “Sister Hills” chronicles the history of Israel’s settlements from the eve of the Yom Kippur War through the present, a political fable constructed around the tale of two mothers who strike a terrible bargain to save a child. Marking a return to two of Englander’s classic themes, “Peep Show” and “How We Avenged the Blums” wrestle with sexual longing and ingenuity in the face of adversity and peril. And “Everything I Know About My Family on My Mother’s Side” is suffused with an intimacy and tenderness that break new ground for a writer who seems constantly to be expanding the parameters of what he can achieve in the short form. \xa0 Beautiful and courageous, funny and achingly sad, Englander’s work is a revelation. In the outlandishly dark &amp;ldquo;Camp Sundown&amp;rdquo; vigilante justice is undertaken by a group of geriatric campers in a bucolic summer enclave. &amp;ldquo;Free Fruit for Young Widows&amp;rdquo; is a small, sharp study in evil, lovingly told by a father to a son. &amp;ldquo;Sister Hills&amp;rdquo; chronicles the history of Israel&amp;rsquo;s settlements from the eve of the Yom Kippur War through the present, a political fable constructed around the tale of two mothers who strike a terrible bargain to save a child. Marking a return to two of Englander&amp;rsquo;s classic themes, &amp;ldquo;Peep Show&amp;rdquo; and &amp;ldquo;How We Avenged the Blums&amp;rdquo; wrestle with sexual longing and ingenuity in the face of adversity and peril. And &amp;ldquo;Everything I Know About My Family on My Mother&amp;rsquo;s Side&amp;rdquo; is suffused with an intimacy and tenderness that break new ground for a writer who seems constantly to be expanding the parameters of what he can achieve in the short form.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n &amp;#160;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n Beautiful and courageous, funny and achingly sad, Englander&amp;rsquo;s work is a revelation."/>\n\t\n    \n\t<title>Listen to What We Talk About When We Talk About Anne Frank: Stories by Nathan Englander at Audiobooks.com  </title>\n\n            <!-- Facebook Pixel Code -->\n                               </div>\r\n                                    </a>\r\n                                </div>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                                                                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-written-by">Written By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/author/16342/nathan-englander">Nathan Englander</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-narrated-by">Narrated By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/narrator/24441/various-readers">Various Readers </a></span></span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-by">Publisher: <span class="nobold">Random House (Audio)</span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-date">Date: <span class="nobold">February 2012</span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                                                            <h4 class="book-duration">Duration: <span class="nobold">7 hours 0 minutes</span></h4>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                        <h4 class="book-summary nopadding">Summary:</h4>\r\n                        <div class="book-description">\r\n                            <p class="hide">These eight new stories from the celebrated novelist and short-story writer Nathan Englander display a gifted young author grappling with the great questions of modern life, with a command of language and the imagination that place Englander at the very forefront of contemporary American fiction.<br />\r\n &#160;<br />\r\n The title story, inspired by Raymond Carver&rsquo;s masterpiece, is a provocative portrait of two marriages in which the Holocaust is played out as a devastating parlor game. In the outlandishly dark &ldquo;Camp Sundown&rdquo; vigilante justice is undertaken by a group of geriatric campers in a bucolic summer enclave. &ldquo;Free Fruit for Young Widows&rdquo; is a small, sharp study in evil, lovingly told by a father to a son. &ldquo;Sister Hills&rdquo; chronicles the history of Israel&rsquo;s settlements from the eve of the Yom Kippur War through the present, a political fable constructed around the tale of two mothers who strike a terrible bargain to save a child. Marking a return to two of Englander&rsquo;s classic themes, &ldquo;Peep Show&rdquo; and &ldquo;How We Avenged the Blums&rdquo; wrestle with sexual longing and ingenuity in the face of adversity and peril. And &ldquo;Everything I Know About My Family on My Mother&rsquo;s Side&rdquo; is suffused with an intimacy and tenderness that break new ground for a writer who seems constantly to be expanding the parameters of what he can achieve in the short form.<br />\r\n &#160;<br />\r\n Beautiful and courageous, funny and achingly sad, Englander&rsquo;s work is a revelation.</p>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                                                <h4>Genres: <div itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" class="no-margin-bottom nobold" id="genre_0"><a class="nobold" itemprop="url" href="https://www.audiobooks.com/browse/fiction_and_literature" genre-id="15"><span itemprop="title">Fiction & Literature</split></a> &gt; <div itemscope itemprop="child" itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" style="display:inline;"><a class="nobold" itemprop="url" href="https://www.audiobooks.com/browse/fiction_and_literature/religious_and_inspirational" genre-id="421"><span itemprop="title">Religious & Inspirational</split></a></div></div><div itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" class="no-margin-bottom nobold" id="genre_1"><a 'https://covers.audiobooks.com/images/covers/full/9781630157661.jpg', None, "In this controversial and provocative book, Mary Anne Franks examines the thin line between constitutional fidelity and constitutional fundamentalism. Constitutional fundamentalists read the Constitution selectively and self-servingly. Fundamentalist interpretations of the Constitution elevate certain constitutional rights above all others, benefit the most powerful members of society, and undermine the integrity of the document as a whole. The conservative fetish for the Second Amendment (enforced by groups such as the NRA) provides an obvious example of constitutional fundamentalism; the liberal fetish for the First Amendment (enforced by groups such as the ACLU) is less obvious but no less influential. Economic and civil libertarianism have increasingly merged to produce a deregulatory, 'free-market' approach to constitutional rights that achieves fullest expression in the idealization of the Internet. The worship of guns, speech, and the Internet in the name of the Constitution has blurred the boundaries between conduct and speech and between veneration and violence. But the Constitution itself contains the antidote to fundamentalism. The Cult of the Constitution lays bare the dark, antidemocratic consequences of constitutional fundamentalism and urges listeners to take the Constitution seriously, not selectively. Fundamentalist interpretations of the Constitution elevate certain constitutional rights above all others, benefit the most powerful members of society, and undermine the integrity of the document as a whole. The conservative fetish for the Second Amendment (enforced by groups such as the NRA) provides an obvious example of constitutional fundamentalism; the liberal fetish for the First Amendment (enforced by groups such as the ACLU) is less obvious but no less influential. Economic and civil libertarianism have increasingly merged to produce a deregulatory, \'free-market\' approach to constitutional rights that achieves fullest expression in the idealization of the Internet. The worship of guns, speech, and the Internet in the name of the Constitution has blurred the boundaries between conduct and speech and between veneration and violence.&lt;br /&gt;\n&lt;br /&gt;\nBut the Constitution itself contains the antidote to fundamentalism. The Cult of the Constitution lays bare the dark, antidemocratic consequences of constitutional fundamentalism and urges listeners to take the Constitution seriously, not selectively."/>\n\t\n            <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-written-by">Written By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/author/213144/mary-anne-franks">Mary Anne Franks</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-narrated-by">Narrated By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/narrator/167970/teri-schnaubelt">Teri Schnaubelt</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-by">Publisher: <span class="nobold">Tantor Media</span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-date">Date: <span class="nobold">July 2019</span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                                                            <h4 class="book-duration">Duration: <span class="nobold">8 hours 58 minutes</span></h4>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                        <h4 class="book-summary nopadding">Summary:</h4>\r\n                        <div class="book-description">\r\n                            <p class="hide">In this controversial and provocative book, Mary Anne Franks examines the thin line between constitutional fidelity and constitutional fundamentalism.<br />\n<br />\nConstitutional fundamentalists read the Constitution selectively and self-servingly. Fundamentalist interpretations of the Constitution elevate certain constitutional rights above all others, benefit the most powerful members of society, and undermine the integrity of the document as a whole. The conservative fetish for the Second Amendment (enforced by groups such as the NRA) provides an obvious example of constitutional fundamentalism; the liberal fetish for the First Amendment (enforced by groups such as the ACLU) is less obvious but no less influential. Economic and civil libertarianism have increasingly merged to produce a deregulatory, \'free-market\' approach to constitutional rights that achieves fullest expression in the idealization of the Internet. The worship of guns, speech, and the Internet in the name of the Constitution has blurred the boundaries between conduct and speech and between veneration and violence.<br />\n<br />\nBut the Constitution itself contains the antidote to fundamentalism. The Cult of the Constitution lays bare the dark, antidemocratic consequences of constitutional fundamentalism and urges listeners to take the Constitution seriously, not selectively.</p>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                                                <h4>Genres: <div itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" class="no-margin-bottom nobold" id="genre_0"><a class="nobold" itemprop="url" href="https://www.audiobooks.com/browse/non-fiction" genre-id="16"><span itemprop="title">Non-Fiction</split></a> &gt; <div itemscope itemprop="child" itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" style="display:inline;"><a class="nobold" itemprop="url" href="https://www.audiobooks.com/browse/non-fiction/law" genre-id="196"><span itemprop="title">Law</split></a></div></div></h4>\r\n                        <!-- <h4>Tags:</h4> -->\r\n                    </div>\r\n                    <div class="line"></div>\r\n\r\n                                                                   <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-written-by">Written By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/author/1928/carol-ann-lee">Carol Ann Lee</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-narrated-by">Narrated By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/narrator/478/barbara-rosenblat">Barbara Rosenblat</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-by">Publisher: <span class="nobold">Blackstone Audiobooks</span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-date">Date: <span class="nobold">February 2012</span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                                                            <h4 class="book-duration">Duration: <span class="nobold">2 hours 13 minutes</span></h4>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                        <h4 class="book-summary nopadding">Summary:</h4>\r\n                        <div class="book-description">\r\n                            <p class="hide">The Diary of Anne Frank is read and loved by children throughout the world, yet few of those readers know what life was really like for the young Jewish girl before and after she wrote her famous diary.<br />\r\nWritten in a lively yet sympathetic style, Anne Frank&rsquo;s Story follows Anne Frank from her birth in Germany and her happy childhood in Amsterdam through the years she and her family spent in hiding from the Nazis to her imprisonment and eventual death in the concentration camps.<br />\r\n&ldquo;This book gives children the opportunity to meet Anne Frank, to know her story and her destiny, and to learn that discrimination in every form is evil and inhuman.&rdquo;&mdash;Buddy Elias, first cousin to Anne Frank</p>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                                                                   <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-written-by">Written By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/author/1928/carol-ann-lee">Carol Ann Lee</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-narrated-by">Narrated By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/narrator/478/barbara-rosenblat">Barbara Rosenblat</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-by">Publisher: <span class="nobold">Blackstone Audiobooks</span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-date">Date: <span class="nobold">February 2012</span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                                                            <h4 class="book-duration">Duration: <span class="nobold">2 hours 13 minutes</span></h4>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                        <h4 class="book-summary nopadding">Summary:</h4>\r\n                        <div class="book-description">\r\n                            <p class="hide">The Diary of Anne Frank is read and loved by children throughout the world, yet few of those readers know what life was really like for the young Jewish girl before and after she wrote her famous diary.<br />\r\nWritten in a lively yet sympathetic style, Anne Frank&rsquo;s Story follows Anne Frank from her birth in Germany and her happy childhood in Amsterdam through the years she and her family spent in hiding from the Nazis to her imprisonment and eventual death in the concentration camps.<br />\r\n&ldquo;This book gives children the opportunity to meet Anne Frank, to know her story and her destiny, and to learn that discrimination in every form is evil and inhuman.&rdquo;&mdash;Buddy Elias, first cousin to Anne Frank</p>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                                                <h4>Genres: <div itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" class="no-margin-bottom nobold" id="genre_0"><a class="nobold" itemprop="url" style="display:inline;"><a class="nobold" itemprop="url" href="https://www.audiobooks.com/browse/kids/biography_and_memoir" genre-id="475"><span itemprop="title">Biography & Memoir</split></a></div></div></h4>\r\n                        <!-- <h4>Tags:</h4> -->\r\n                    </div>\r\n                    <div class="line"></div>\r\n\r\n                    <!-- bestselling author Ryan Holiday made ancient wisdom wildly popular with a new generation of leaders in sports, politics, and technology. In his new book, Stillness Is the Key, Holiday draws on timeless Stoic and Buddhist philosophy to show why slowing down is the secret weapon for those charging ahead. All great leaders, thinkers, artists, athletes, and visionaries share one indelible quality. It enables them to conquer their tempers. To avoid distraction and discover great insights. To achieve happiness and do the right thing. Ryan Holiday calls it stillness--to be steady while the world spins around you.  In this book, he outlines a path for achieving this ancient, but urgently necessary way of living. Drawing on a wide range of history's greatest thinkers, from Confucius to Seneca, Marcus Aurelius to Thich Nhat Hanh, John Stuart Mill to Nietzsche, he argues that stillness is not mere inactivity, but the doorway to self-mastery, discipline, and focus. Holiday also examines figures who exemplified the power of stillness: baseball player Sadaharu Oh, whose study of Zen made him the greatest home run hitter of all time; Winston Churchill, who in balancing his busy public life with time spent laying bricks and painting at his Chartwell estate managed to save the world from annihilation in the process; Fred Rogers, who taught generations of children to see what was invisible to the eye; Anne Frank, whose journaling and love of nature guided her through unimaginable adversity.  More than ever, people are overwhelmed. They face obstacles and egos and competition. Stillness Is the Key offers a simple but inspiring antidote to the stress of 24/7 news and social media. The stillness that we all seek is the path to meaning, contentment, and excellence in a world that needs more of it than ever. In his new book, Stillness Is the Key, Holiday draws on timeless Stoic and Buddhist philosophy to show why slowing down is the secret weapon for those charging ahead.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nAll great leaders, thinkers, artists, athletes, and visionaries share one indelible quality. It enables them to conquer their tempers. To avoid distraction and discover great insights. To achieve happiness and do the right thing. Ryan Holiday calls it stillness--to be steady while the world spins around you. &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nIn this book, he outlines a path for achieving this ancient, but urgently necessary way of living. Drawing on a wide range of history\'s greatest thinkers, from Confucius to Seneca, Marcus Aurelius to Thich Nhat Hanh, John Stuart Mill to Nietzsche, he argues that stillness is not mere inactivity, but the doorway to self-mastery, discipline, and focus.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nHoliday also examines figures who exemplified the power of stillness: baseball player Sadaharu Oh, whose study of Zen made him the greatest home run hitter of all time; Winston Churchill, who in balancing his busy public life with time spent laying bricks and painting at his Chartwell estate managed to save the world from annihilation in the process; Fred Rogers, who taught generations of children to see what was invisible to the eye; Anne Frank, whose journaling and love of nature guided her through unimaginable adversity. &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nMore than ever, people are overwhelmed. They face obstacles and egos and competition. Stillness Is the Key offers a simple but inspiring antidote to the stress of 24/7 news and social media. The stillness that we all seek is the path to meaning, contentment, and excellence in a world that needs more of it than ever."/>\n\t\n    \n\t<title>Listen to Stillness is the Key by Ryan Holiday at          </div>\r\n                                    </a>\r\n                                </div>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                                                                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-written-by">Written By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/author/38145/ryan-holiday">Ryan Holiday</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-narrated-by">Narrated By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/narrator/38145/ryan-holiday">Ryan Holiday</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-by">Publisher: <span class="nobold">Penguin Audio</span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-date">Date: <span class="nobold">October 2019</span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                                                            <h4 class="book-duration">Duration: <span class="nobold">6 hours 56 minutes</span></h4>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                        <h4 class="book-summary nopadding">Summary:</h4>\r\n                        <div class="book-description">\r\n                            <p class="hide">Instant #1 New York Times Bestseller &amp; Wall Street Journal Bestseller<br />\r\n<br />\r\nIn The Obstacle Is the Way and Ego Is the Enemy, bestselling author Ryan Holiday made ancient wisdom wildly popular with a new generation of leaders in sports, politics, and technology. In his new book, Stillness Is the Key, Holiday draws on timeless Stoic and Buddhist philosophy to show why slowing down is the secret weapon for those charging ahead.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nAll great leaders, thinkers, artists, athletes, and visionaries share one indelible quality. It enables them to conquer their tempers. To avoid distraction and discover great insights. To achieve happiness and do the right thing. Ryan Holiday calls it stillness--to be steady while the world spins around you. <br />\r\n<br />\r\nIn this book, he outlines a path for achieving this ancient, but urgently necessary way of living. Drawing on a wide range of history\'s greatest thinkers, from Confucius to Seneca, Marcus Aurelius to Thich Nhat Hanh, John Stuart Mill to Nietzsche, he argues that stillness is not mere inactivity, but the doorway to self-mastery, discipline, and focus.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nHoliday also examines figures who exemplified the power of stillness: baseball player Sadaharu Oh, whose study of Zen made him the greatest home run hitter of all time; Winston Churchill, who in balancing his busy public life with time spent laying bricks and painting at his Chartwell estate managed to save the world from annihilation in the process; Fred Rogers, who taught generations of children to see what was invisible to the eye; Anne Frank, whose journaling and love of nature guided her through unimaginable adversity. <br />\r\n<br />\r\nMore than ever, people are overwhelmed. They face obstacles and egos and competition. Stillness Is the Key offers a simple but inspiring antidote to the stress of 24/7 news and social media. The stillness that we all seek is the path to meaning, contentment, and excellence in a world that needs more of it than ever.</p>\r\n                        </div>\r\n True, None], 0.4], [['AUDIOBOOK', 'The Freedom Writers Diary: How a Teacher and 150 Teens Used Writing to Change Themselves and the World Around Them', <PIL.Image.Image image mode=L size=344x317 at 0x213C2F1EC88>, 'https://covers.audiobooks.com/images/covers/full/9781415928653.jpg', None, '#1 NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER •\xa0The twentieth anniversary edition of the classic story of an incredible group of students and the teacher who inspired them, featuring updates on the students’ lives, new journal entries, and an introduction by Erin Gruwell \xa0 Now a public television documentary,\xa0Freedom Writers: Stories from the Heart \xa0 In 1994, an idealistic first-year teacher in Long Beach, California, named Erin Gruwell confronted a room of “unteachable, at-risk” students. She had intercepted a note with an ugly racial caricature and angrily declared that this was precisely the sort of thing that led to the Holocaust. She was met by uncomprehending looks—none of her students had heard of one of the defining moments of the twentieth century. So she rebooted her entire curriculum, using treasured books such as Anne Frank’s diary as her guide to combat intolerance and misunderstanding. Her students began recording their thoughts and feelings in their own diaries, eventually dubbing themselves the “Freedom Writers.” \xa0 Consisting of powerful entries from the students’ diaries and narrative text by Erin Gruwell,\xa0The Freedom Writers Diary\xa0is an unforgettable story of how hard work, courage, and determination changed the lives of a teacher and her students. In the two decades since its original publication, the book has sold more than one million copies and inspired a major motion picture\xa0Freedom Writers. She had intercepted a note with an ugly racial caricature and angrily declared that this was precisely the sort of thing that led to the Holocaust. She was met by uncomprehending looks&amp;mdash;none of her students had heard of one of the defining moments of the twentieth century. So she rebooted her entire curriculum, using treasured books such as Anne Frank&amp;rsquo;s diary as her guide to combat intolerance and misunderstanding. Her students began recording their thoughts and feelings in their own diaries, eventually dubbing themselves the &amp;ldquo;Freedom Writers.&amp;rdquo;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;#160;&lt;br /&gt;\r\nConsisting of powerful entries from the students&amp;rsquo; diaries and narrative text by Erin Gruwell,&amp;#160;The Freedom Writers Diary&amp;#160;is an unforgettable story of how hard work, courage, and determination changed the lives of a teacher and her students. In the two decades since its original publication, the book has sold more than one million copies and inspired a major motion picture&amp;#160;Freedom Writers. And now, with this twentieth-anniversary edition, readers are brought up to date on the lives of the Freedom Writers, as they blend indispensable takes on social issues with uplifting stories of attending college&amp;mdash;and watch their own children follow in their footsteps.&amp;#160;The Freedom Writers Diary&amp;#160;remains a vital read for anyone who believes in second chances."/>\n\t\n                                                                   <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-written-by">Written By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/author/54672/erin-gruwell">Erin Gruwell</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-narrated-by">Narrated By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/narrator/7920/cassandra-campbell">Cassandra Campbell</a></span>, <span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/narrator/13903/dominic-hoffman">Dominic Hoffman</a></span>, <span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/narrator/16629/bahni-turpin">Bahni Turpin</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-by">Publisher: <span class="nobold">Random House (Audio)</span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-date">Date: <span class="nobold">January 2006</span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                                                            <h4 class="book-duration">Duration: <span class="nobold">9 hours 34 minutes</span></h4>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                        <h4 class="book-summary nopadding">Summary:</h4>\r\n                        <div class="book-description">\r\n                            <p class="hide">#1 NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER &bull;&#160;The twentieth anniversary edition of the classic story of an incredible group of students and the teacher who inspired them, featuring updates on the students&rsquo; lives, new journal entries, and an introduction by Erin Gruwell<br />\r\n&#160;<br />\r\nNow a public television documentary,&#160;Freedom Writers: Stories from the Heart<br />\r\n&#160;<br />\r\nIn 1994, an idealistic first-year teacher in Long Beach, California, named Erin Gruwell confronted a room of &ldquo;unteachable, at-risk&rdquo; students. She had intercepted a note with an ugly racial caricature and angrily declared that this was precisely the sort of thing that led to the Holocaust. She was met by uncomprehending looks&mdash;none of her students had heard of one of the defining moments of the twentieth century. So she rebooted her entire curriculum, using treasured books such as Anne Frank&rsquo;s diary as her guide to combat intolerance and misunderstanding. Her students began recording their thoughts and feelings in their own diaries, eventually dubbing themselves the &ldquo;Freedom Writers.&rdquo;<br />\r\n&#160;<br />\r\nConsisting of powerful entries from the students&rsquo; diaries and narrative text by Erin Gruwell,&#160;The Freedom Writers Diary&#160;is an unforgettable story of how hard work, courage, and determination changed the lives of a teacher and her students. In the two decades since its original publication, the book has sold more than one million copies and inspired a major motion picture&#160;Freedom Writers. And now, with this twentieth-anniversary edition, readers are brought up to date on the lives of the Freedom Writers, as they blend indispensable takes on social issues with uplifting stories of attending college&mdash;and watch their own children follow in their footsteps.&#160;The Freedom Writers Diary&#160;remains a vital read for anyone who believes in second chances.</p>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                                                <h4>Genres: <div itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" class="no-margin-bottom nobold" id="genre_0"><a                                                          <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-written-by">Written By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/author/15658/markus-zusak">Markus Zusak</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-narrated-by">Narrated By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/narrator/375/allan-corduner">Allan Corduner</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-by">Publisher: <span class="nobold">Listening Library (Audio)</span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-date">Date: <span class="nobold">September 2006</span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                                                            <h4 class="book-duration">Duration: <span class="nobold">13 hours 57 minutes</span></h4>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                        <h4 class="book-summary nopadding">Summary:</h4>\r\n                        <div class="book-description">\r\n                            <p class="hide">DON&rsquo;T MISS BRIDGE OF CLAY, MARKUS ZUSAK&rsquo;S FIRST NOVEL SINCE THE BOOK THIEF.<br />\r\n &#160;<br />\r\nThe extraordinary #1&#160;New York Times&#160;bestseller that is now a major motion picture, Markus Zusak\'s unforgettable story is about the ability of books to feed the soul.<br />\r\n &#160;<br />\r\nNominated as one of America\'s best-loved novels by&#160;PBS&rsquo;s&#160;The Great American Read.  <br />\r\n<br />\r\nWhen Death has a story to tell, you listen.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n It is 1939. Nazi Germany. The country is holding its breath. Death has never been busier, and will become busier still.<br />\r\n<br />\r\n Liesel Meminger is a foster girl living outside of Munich, who scratches out a meager existence for herself by stealing when she encounters something she can&rsquo;t resist&ndash;books. With the help of her accordion-playing foster father, she learns to read and shares her stolen books with her neighbors during bombing raids as well as with the Jewish man hidden in her basement.&#160;<br />\r\n<br />\r\n In superbly crafted writing that burns with intensity, award-winning author Markus Zusak, author of&#160;I Am the Messenger,&#160;has given us one of the most enduring stories of our time.<br />\r\n &#160;<br />\r\n &ldquo;The kind of book that can be life-changing.&rdquo; &mdash;The New York Times<br />\r\n &#160;<br />\r\n &ldquo;Deserves a place on the same shelf with The Diary of a Young Girl by Anne Frank.&rdquo; &mdash;USA Today</p>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                                                <h4>Genres: <div itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" class="no-margin-bottom nobold" id="genre_0"><a class="nobold" itemprop="url" href="https://www.audiobooks.com/browse/teen" genre-id="254"><span itemprop="title">Teen</split></a> &gt; <div itemscope itemprop="child" itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" style="display:inline;"><a class="nobold" itemprop="url"                    </div>\r\n                                                </div>\r\n                                                <p class="book-rating-description nomargin">This is the most amazing book! It is written flawlessly and the narration adds a whole new feel to the story! I have listened to this countless times and it never gets old! A</p>\r\n                                                <p class="tright nomargin review-helpfulness">3 of 3 people found this review helpful.</p>                                            </div>\r\n                                    \t</li>\r\n                                \t                                \t\t<li class="clearfix">\r\n                                            <div class="spost-content clearfix">\r\n                                                <div class="user-reviews">\r\n                                                    <div class="clearfix">\r\n                                                        <div class="fleft">\r\n                                                            <h5 class="nopadding">Jason J.</h5>\r\n                                                        </div>\r\n                                                        <div class="fleft">\r\n                                                            <span class="book-rating" data-score="5"></span>\r\n                                                        </div>\r\n                                                    </div>\r\n                                                </div>\r\n                                                <p class="book-rating-description nomargin">I loved this book. I am not a big fan of revisionist history but this is different. It is adding to our understanding of the \xe2\x80\x9cenemy\xe2\x80\x9d in those days. This book is adolescent at times, even elementary, but that abandonment of conventions is brilliant. A book should be delivered to the reader in a manner that opens there mind without requiring a PhD to catch up.</p>\r\n                                                <p class="tright nomargin review-helpfulness">3 of 3 people found this review helpful.</p>                                            </div>\r\n                                    \t</li>\r\n                                \t                                \t\t<li class="clearfix">\r\n                                            <div class="spost-content clearfix">\r\n                                                <div class="user-reviews">\r\n                                                    <div class="clearfix">\r\n                                                        <div class="fleft">\r\n                                                            <h5 class="nopadding">Robert E.</h5>\r\n                                                        </div>\r\n                                                        <div class="fleft">\r\n                                                            <span class="book-rating" data-score="5"></span>\r\n                                                        </div>\r\n                                                    </div>\r\n                                                </div>\r\n                                                <p class="book-rating-description nomargin">I loved the book.         <p class="book-rating-description nomargin">I don\'t know what I was expecting but it wasn\'t this book.  It took me a bit to get into ... then I did.  Excellent writing!  Excellent narration!  Terrific story!  I felt as if I were there as the story unfolded.  A different view of Germany during WWII.  Felt emotional at the end. elem = $(this);\r\n                        var action = elem.data(\'action\');\r\n                        var bookId = elem.data(\'bookid\');\r\n                        var title = elem.data(\'title\');\r\n                        if(action == \'cancel\'){\r\n                            return false;\r\n                        }\r\n                        else{\r\n                            var body = $(\'#comingSoon__modal\').html();\r\n On the surface she lives a quiet life, but Margie has a secret: a life she once lived, a past and a religion she has denied, and a family and a country she left behind.            <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-written-by">Written By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/author/107629/jillian-cantor">Jillian Cantor</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-narrated-by">Narrated By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/narrator/20740/rachel-botchan">Rachel Botchan</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-by">Publisher: <span class="nobold">Recorded Books</span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-date">Date: <span class="nobold">January 2014</span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                                                            <h4 class="book-duration">Duration: <span class="nobold">10 hours 1 minutes</span></h4>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                        <h4 class="book-summary nopadding">Summary:</h4>\r\n                        <div class="book-description">\r\n                            <p class="hide">Anne Frank has long been a symbol of bravery and hope, but there were two sisters hidden in the annex, two young Jewish girls, one a cultural icon made famous by her published diary and the other, nearly forgotten. In the spring of 1959, The Diary of Anne Frank has just come to the silver screen to great acclaim, and a young woman named Margie Franklin is working in Philadelphia as a secretary at a Jewish law firm. On the surface she lives a quiet life, but Margie has a secret: a life she once lived, a past and a religion she has denied, and a family and a country she left behind. Margie Franklin is really Margot Frank, older sister of Anne, who did not die in Bergen-Belsen as reported, but who instead escaped the Nazis for America. But now, as her sister becomes a global icon, Margie\' s carefully constructed American life begins to fall apart. A new relationship threatens to overtake the young love that sustained her during the war, and her past and present begin to collide. Margie is forced to come to terms with Margot, with the people she loved, and with a life swept up into the course of history.</p>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                                                <h4>Genres: <div itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" class="no-margin-bottom nobold" id="genre_0"><a class="nobold" itemprop="url" href="https://www.audiobooks.com/browse/fiction_and_literature" genre-id="15"><span itemprop="title">Fiction & Literature</split></a> &gt; <div itemscope itemprop="child" itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" style="display:inline;"><a class="nobold" itemprop="url" href="https://www.audiobooks.com/browse/literature/literary_fiction" genre-id="103"><span itemprop="title">Literary Fiction</split></a></div></div></h4>\r\n                        <!-- <h4>Tags:</h4> -->\r\n                    </div>\r\n                    <div class="line"></div>\r\n\r\n True, None], 0.4], [['AUDIOBOOK', "Renia's Diary: A Holocaust Journal", <PIL.Image.Image image mode=L size=344x344 at 0x213C2EE0648>, 'https://covers.audiobooks.com/images/covers/full/9781250245953.jpg', None, 'A New York Times bestseller A USA Today bestseller  The long-hidden diary of a young Polish woman\'s life during the Holocaust, translated for the first time into English Renia Spiegel was born in 1924 to an upper-middle class Jewish family living in southeastern Poland, near what was at that time the border with Romania. At the start of 1939 Renia began a diary. "I just want a friend. I want somebody to talk to about my everyday worries and joys. Somebody who would feel what I feel, who would believe me, who would never reveal my secrets. A human being can never be such a friend and that\'s why I have decided to look for a confidant in the form of a diary." And so begins an extraordinary document of an adolescent girl\'s hopes and dreams. By the fall of 1939, Renia and her younger sister Elizabeth (née Ariana) were staying with their grandparents in Przemysl, a city in the south, just as the German and Soviet armies invaded Poland. Cut off from their mother, who was in Warsaw, Renia and her family were plunged into war. Like Anne Frank, Renia\'s diary became a record of her daily life as the Nazis spread throughout Europe. Renia writes of her mundane school life, her daily drama with best friends, falling in love with her boyfriend Zygmund, as well as the agony of missing her mother, separated by bombs and invading armies. Renia had aspirations to be a writer, and the diary is filled with her poignant and thoughtful poetry. When she was forced into the city\'s ghetto with the other Jews, Zygmund is able to smuggle her out to hide with his parents, taking Renia out of the ghetto, but not, ultimately to safety. The diary ends in July 1942, completed by Zygmund, after Renia is murdered by the Gestapo. Renia\'s Diary has been translated from the original Polish, and includes a preface, afterword, and notes by her surviving sister, Elizabeth Bellak. An extraordinary historical document, Renia Spiegel survives through the beauty of her words and the efforts of those who loved her and preserved her legacy. At the start of 1939 Renia began a diary. &quot;I just want a friend. I want somebody to talk to about my everyday worries and joys. Somebody who would feel what I feel, who would believe me, who would never reveal my secrets. A human being can never be such a friend and that\'s why I have decided to look for a confidant in the form of a diary.&quot; And so begins an extraordinary document of an adolescent girl\'s hopes and dreams. By the fall of 1939, Renia and her younger sister Elizabeth (n&eacute;e Ariana) were staying with their grandparents in Przemysl, a city in the south, just as the German and Soviet armies invaded Poland. Cut off from their mother, who was in Warsaw, Renia and her family were plunged into war.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nLike Anne Frank, Renia\'s diary became a record of her daily life as the Nazis spread throughout Europe. Renia writes of her mundane school life, her daily drama with best friends, falling in love with her boyfriend Zygmund, as well as the agony of missing her mother, separated by bombs and invading armies. Renia had aspirations to be a writer, and the diary is filled with her poignant and thoughtful poetry. When she was forced into the city\'s ghetto with the other Jews, Zygmund is able to smuggle her out to hide with his parents, taking Renia out of the ghetto, but not, ultimately to safety. The diary ends in July 1942, completed by Zygmund, after Renia is murdered by the Gestapo.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nRenia\'s Diary has been translated from the original Polish, and includes a preface, afterword, and notes by her surviving sister, Elizabeth Bellak. An extraordinary historical document, Renia Spiegel survives through the beauty of her words and the efforts of those who loved her and preserved her legacy."/>\n\t\n    \n\t<title>Listen to Renia\'s          </div>\r\n                                    </a>\r\n                                </div>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                                                                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-written-by">Written By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/author/202729/renia-spiegel">Renia Spiegel</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-narrated-by">Narrated By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/narrator/31889/ann-richardson">Ann Richardson</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-by">Publisher: <span class="nobold">Macmillan Audio</span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-date">Date: <span class="nobold">September 2019</span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                                                            <h4 class="book-duration">Duration: <span class="nobold">12 hours 54 minutes</span></h4>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                        <h4 class="book-summary nopadding">Summary:</h4>\r\n                        <div class="book-description">\r\n                            <p class="hide">A New York Times bestseller<br />\r\nA USA Today bestseller <br />\r\n The long-hidden diary of a young Polish woman\'s life during the Holocaust, translated for the first time into English<br />\r\nRenia Spiegel was born in 1924 to an upper-middle class Jewish family living in southeastern Poland, near what was at that time the border with Romania. At the start of 1939 Renia began a diary. "I just want a friend. I want somebody to talk to about my everyday worries and joys. Somebody who would feel what I feel, who would believe me, who would never reveal my secrets. A human being can never be such a friend and that\'s why I have decided to look for a confidant in the form of a diary." And so begins an extraordinary document of an adolescent girl\'s hopes and dreams. By the fall of 1939, Renia and her younger sister Elizabeth (n\xc3\xa9e Ariana) were staying with their grandparents in Przemysl, a city in the south, just as the German and Soviet armies invaded Poland. Cut off from their mother, who was in Warsaw, Renia and her family were plunged into war.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nLike Anne Frank, Renia\'s diary became a record of her daily life as the Nazis spread throughout Europe. Renia writes of her mundane school life, her daily drama with best friends, falling in love with her boyfriend Zygmund, as well as the agony of missing her mother, separated by bombs and invading armies. Renia had aspirations to be a writer, and the diary is filled with her poignant and thoughtful poetry. When she was forced into the city\'s ghetto with the other Jews, Zygmund is able to smuggle her out to hide with his parents, taking Renia out of the ghetto, but not, ultimately to safety. The diary ends in July 1942, completed by Zygmund, after Renia is murdered by the Gestapo.<br />\r\nRenia\'s Diary has been translated from the original Polish, and includes a preface, afterword, and notes by her surviving sister, Elizabeth Bellak. An extraordinary historical document, Renia Spiegel survives through the beauty of her words and the efforts of those who loved her and preserved her legacy.</p>\r\n                        </div>\r\n genre-id="250"><span itemprop="title">History & Culture</split></a></div></div><div itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" class="no-margin-bottom nobold" id="genre_1"><a "Instant #1 New York Times Bestseller & Wall Street Journal Bestseller In The Obstacle Is the Way and Ego Is the Enemy, bestselling author Ryan Holiday made ancient wisdom wildly popular with a new generation of leaders in sports, politics, and technology. In his new book, Stillness Is the Key, Holiday draws on timeless Stoic and Buddhist philosophy to show why slowing down is the secret weapon for those charging ahead. All great leaders, thinkers, artists, athletes, and visionaries share one indelible quality. It enables them to conquer their tempers. To avoid distraction and discover great insights. To achieve happiness and do the right thing. Ryan Holiday calls it stillness--to be steady while the world spins around you.  In this book, he outlines a path for achieving this ancient, but urgently necessary way of living. Drawing on a wide range of history's greatest thinkers, from Confucius to Seneca, Marcus Aurelius to Thich Nhat Hanh, John Stuart Mill to Nietzsche, he argues that stillness is not mere inactivity, but the doorway to self-mastery, discipline, and focus. Holiday also examines figures who exemplified the power of stillness: baseball player Sadaharu Oh, whose study of Zen made him the greatest home run hitter of all time; Winston Churchill, who in balancing his busy public life with time spent laying bricks and painting at his Chartwell estate managed to save the world from annihilation in the process; Fred Rogers, who taught generations of children to see what was invisible to the eye; Anne Frank, whose journaling and love of nature guided her through unimaginable adversity.  More than ever, people are overwhelmed. They face obstacles and egos and competition. Stillness Is the Key offers a simple but inspiring antidote to the stress of 24/7 news and social media. The stillness that we all seek is the path to meaning, contentment, and excellence in a world that needs more of it than ever. In his new book, Stillness Is the Key, Holiday draws on timeless Stoic and Buddhist philosophy to show why slowing down is the secret weapon for those charging ahead.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nAll great leaders, thinkers, artists, athletes, and visionaries share one indelible quality. It enables them to conquer their tempers. To avoid distraction and discover great insights. To achieve happiness and do the right thing. Ryan Holiday calls it stillness--to be steady while the world spins around you. &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nIn this book, he outlines a path for achieving this ancient, but urgently necessary way of living. Drawing on a wide range of history\'s greatest thinkers, from Confucius to Seneca, Marcus Aurelius to Thich Nhat Hanh, John Stuart Mill to Nietzsche, he argues that stillness is not mere inactivity, but the doorway to self-mastery, discipline, and focus.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nHoliday also examines figures who exemplified the power of stillness: baseball player Sadaharu Oh, whose study of Zen made him the greatest home run hitter of all time; Winston Churchill, who in balancing his busy public life with time spent laying bricks and painting at his Chartwell estate managed to save the world from annihilation in the process; Fred Rogers, who taught generations of children to see what was invisible to the eye; Anne Frank, whose journaling and love of nature guided her through unimaginable adversity. &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nMore than ever, people are overwhelmed. They face obstacles and egos and competition. Stillness Is the Key offers a simple but inspiring antidote to the stress of 24/7 news and social media. The stillness that we all seek is the path to meaning, contentment, and excellence in a world that needs more of it than ever."/>\n\t\n    \n\t<title>Listen to Stillness is the Key by Ryan Holiday at          </div>\r\n                                    </a>\r\n                                </div>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                                                                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-written-by">Written By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/author/38145/ryan-holiday">Ryan Holiday</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-narrated-by">Narrated By: <span class="nobold"><span class="no-margin-bottom bold"><a href="/browse/narrator/38145/ryan-holiday">Ryan Holiday</a></span></span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-by">Publisher: <span class="nobold">Penguin Audio</span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-date">Date: <span class="nobold">October 2019</span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                                                            <h4 class="book-duration">Duration: <span class="nobold">6 hours 56 minutes</span></h4>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                        <h4 class="book-summary nopadding">Summary:</h4>\r\n                        <div class="book-description">\r\n                            <p class="hide">Instant #1 New York Times Bestseller &amp; Wall Street Journal Bestseller<br />\r\n<br />\r\nIn The Obstacle Is the Way and Ego Is the Enemy, bestselling author Ryan Holiday made ancient wisdom wildly popular with a new generation of leaders in sports, politics, and technology. In his new book, Stillness Is the Key, Holiday draws on timeless Stoic and Buddhist philosophy to show why slowing down is the secret weapon for those charging ahead.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nAll great leaders, thinkers, artists, athletes, and visionaries share one indelible quality. It enables them to conquer their tempers. To avoid distraction and discover great insights. To achieve happiness and do the right thing. Ryan Holiday calls it stillness--to be steady while the world spins around you. <br />\r\n<br />\r\nIn this book, he outlines a path for achieving this ancient, but urgently necessary way of living. Drawing on a wide range of history\'s greatest thinkers, from Confucius to Seneca, Marcus Aurelius to Thich Nhat Hanh, John Stuart Mill to Nietzsche, he argues that stillness is not mere inactivity, but the doorway to self-mastery, discipline, and focus.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nHoliday also examines figures who exemplified the power of stillness: baseball player Sadaharu Oh, whose study of Zen made him the greatest home run hitter of all time; Winston Churchill, who in balancing his busy public life with time spent laying bricks and painting at his Chartwell estate managed to save the world from annihilation in the process; Fred Rogers, who taught generations of children to see what was invisible to the eye; Anne Frank, whose journaling and love of nature guided her through unimaginable adversity. <br />\r\n<br />\r\nMore than ever, people are overwhelmed. They face obstacles and egos and competition. Stillness Is the Key offers a simple but inspiring antidote to the stress of 24/7 news and social media. The stillness that we all seek is the path to meaning, contentment, and excellence in a world that needs more of it than ever.</p>\r\n                        </div>\r\n True, None], 0.4], [['AUDIOBOOK', "Renia's Diary: A Holocaust Journal", <PIL.Image.Image image mode=L size=344x344 at 0x213C30FE548>, 'https://covers.audiobooks.com/images/covers/full/9781250245953.jpg', None, 'A New York Times bestseller A USA Today bestseller  The long-hidden diary of a young Polish woman\'s life during the Holocaust, translated for the first time into English Renia Spiegel was born in 1924 to an upper-middle class Jewish family living in southeastern Poland, near what was at that time the border with Romania. At the start of 1939 Renia began a diary. "I just want a friend. I want somebody to talk to about my everyday worries and joys. Somebody who would feel what I feel, who would believe me, who would never reveal my secrets. A human being can never be such a friend and that\'s why I have decided to look for a confidant in the form of a diary." And so begins an extraordinary document of an adolescent girl\'s hopes and dreams. By the fall of 1939, Renia and her younger sister Elizabeth (née Ariana) were staying with their grandparents in Przemysl, a city in the south, just as the German and Soviet armies invaded Poland. Cut off from their mother, who was in Warsaw, Renia and her family were plunged into war. Like Anne Frank, Renia\'s diary became a record of her daily life as the Nazis spread throughout Europe. Renia writes of her mundane school life, her daily drama with best friends, falling in love with her boyfriend Zygmund, as well as the agony of missing her mother, separated by bombs and invading armies. Renia had aspirations to be a writer, and the diary is filled with her poignant and thoughtful poetry. When she was forced into the city\'s ghetto with the other Jews, Zygmund is able to smuggle her out to hide with his parents, taking Renia out of the ghetto, but not, ultimately to safety. The diary ends in July 1942, completed by Zygmund, after Renia is murdered by the Gestapo. Renia\'s Diary has been translated from the original Polish, and includes a preface, afterword, and notes by her surviving sister, Elizabeth Bellak. An extraordinary historical document, Renia Spiegel survives through the beauty of her words and the efforts of those who loved her and preserved her legacy. At the start of 1939 Renia began a diary. &quot;I just want a friend. I want somebody to talk to about my everyday worries and joys. Somebody who would feel what I feel, who would believe me, who would never reveal my secrets. A human being can never be such a friend and that\'s why I have decided to look for a confidant in the form of a diary.&quot; And so begins an extraordinary document of an adolescent girl\'s hopes and dreams. By the fall of 1939, Renia and her younger sister Elizabeth (n&eacute;e Ariana) were staying with their grandparents in Przemysl, a city in the south, just as the German and Soviet armies invaded Poland. Cut off from their mother, who was in Warsaw, Renia and her family were plunged into war.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nLike Anne Frank, Renia\'s diary became a record of her daily life as the Nazis spread throughout Europe. Renia writes of her mundane school life, her daily drama with best friends, falling in love with her boyfriend Zygmund, as well as the agony of missing her mother, separated by bombs and invading armies. Renia had aspirations to be a writer, and the diary is filled with her poignant and thoughtful poetry. When she was forced into the city\'s ghetto with the other Jews, Zygmund is able to smuggle her out to hide with his parents, taking Renia out of the ghetto, but not, ultimately to safety. The diary ends in July 1942, completed by Zygmund, after Renia is murdered by the Gestapo.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nRenia\'s Diary has been translated from the original Polish, and includes a preface, afterword, and notes by her surviving sister, Elizabeth Bellak. An extraordinary historical document, Renia Spiegel survives through the beauty of her words and the efforts of those who loved her and preserved her legacy."/>\n\t\n    \n\t<title>Listen to Renia\'s <div class="clearfix">\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-by">Publisher: <span class="nobold">Macmillan Audio</span></h4>\r\n                            <h4 class="book-published-date">Date: <span class="nobold">September 2019</span></h4>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                        <div class="clearfix">\r\n                                                            <h4 class="book-duration">Duration: <span class="nobold">12 hours 54 minutes</span></h4>\r\n                                                                                </div>\r\n                        <h4 class="book-summary nopadding">Summary:</h4>\r\n                        <div class="book-description">\r\n                            <p class="hide">A New York Times bestseller<br />\r\nA USA Today bestseller <br />\r\n The long-hidden diary of a young Polish woman\'s life during the Holocaust, translated for the first time into English<br />\r\nRenia Spiegel was born in 1924 to an upper-middle class Jewish family living in southeastern Poland, near what was at that time the border with Romania. At the start of 1939 Renia began a diary. "I just want a friend. I want somebody to talk to about my everyday worries and joys. Somebody who would feel what I feel, who would believe me, who would never reveal my secrets. A human being can never be such a friend and that\'s why I have decided to look for a confidant in the form of a diary." And so begins an extraordinary document of an adolescent girl\'s hopes and dreams. By the fall of 1939, Renia and her younger sister Elizabeth (n\xc3\xa9e Ariana) were staying with their grandparents in Przemysl, a city in the south, just as the German and Soviet armies invaded Poland. Cut off from their mother, who was in Warsaw, Renia and her family were plunged into war.<br />\r\n<br />\r\nLike Anne Frank, Renia\'s diary became a record of her daily life as the Nazis spread throughout Europe. Renia writes of her mundane school life, her daily drama with best friends, falling in love with her boyfriend Zygmund, as well as the agony of missing her mother, separated by bombs and invading armies. Renia had aspirations to be a writer, and the diary is filled with her poignant and thoughtful poetry. When she was forced into the city\'s ghetto with the other Jews, Zygmund is able to smuggle her out to hide with his parents, taking Renia out of the ghetto, but not, ultimately to safety. The diary ends in July 1942, completed by Zygmund, after Renia is murdered by the Gestapo.<br />\r\nRenia\'s Diary has been translated from the original Polish, and includes a preface, afterword, and notes by her surviving sister, Elizabeth Bellak. An extraordinary historical document, Renia Spiegel survives through the beauty of her words and the efforts of those who loved her and preserved her legacy.</p>\r\n                        </div>\r\n                                                <h4>Genres: <div itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" class="no-margin-bottom nobold" id="genre_0"><a class="nobold" itemprop="url" genre-id="250"><span itemprop="title">History & Culture</split></a></div></div><div itemscope itemtype="http://data-vocabulary.org/Breadcrumb" class="no-margin-bottom nobold" id="genre_1"><a
